caption_original: Rhiannon is installing a to help the Automated Recording Unit operate year-round to record bird calls. .Maintaining the stations in the winter is much more cost effective, because there are winter roads (ice roads) in the Northwest Territories! Not only do the recordings tell us what birds are present, but we also learn when birds arrive to the north in the spring and when they depart for warmer southern locations. As well, there are some bird calls which are difficult for the human ear to pick up, especially if other birds are calling at the same time (e.g. Ruffed Grouse); these units allow us to record ALL the sounds, including the tricky quiet ones .....

caption_original: !One of our landscape ecologists studies windbreaks and hedgerows which provide important habitat for pollinators including native Canadian bee species. Her two-year project allows us to have baseline data to see if, how, and where bee species are affected. This is long-term data is especially important in the context of climate change and land-use modification.

caption_original: Meet one of our ARUs! ARU stands for Automated Recording Unit and it records the sounds birds make! The unit has an SD card which can record hours of sound! . ARUs are waterproof because they are left out for a whole year! caption_original: Our biologists spotted species of birds while on a quick stroll into the frozen wetlands of John Lusby Marsh National Wildlife Area for the Amherst, Nova Scotia Christmas Bird Count. Nearly half of them were Arctic breeding migratory birds that reach the Atlantic Provinces in winter, such as the Snow Bunting (aka the ‚Äúsnowflake‚Äù), Lapland Longspur, Rough-legged Hawk, as well as Glaucous and Iceland Gulls. During their short visit, the team was especially surprised to find three Short-eared Owls flying together as a group, a rare delight!...

caption_original: Some our staff working out of Eureka and Sable Island Weather Stations participated in Earth Hour last night and sent us exclusive photos!On Sable island, they shut off all the lights in the office (There were people working in there! When the exterior office photo was taken) and residence, and turned off any excess electronics that they could. Essential monitoring equipment and exterior lights on automatic timers had to be left on. The stars were out and beautiful last night on Sable Island. Earth Hour provided extra incentive to head outside and enjoy the natural beauty of the star filled night sky.At the Eureka Weather Station in the High Arctic (80¬∞ North). We have a permanent staff of to people but during the spring/summer months Scientists and Adventurers come from all over.Some members of the Eureka Crew went outside celebrating Earth Hour to show that we are making their way towards hr daylight (April ) no candles were actually needed there! Each day they all contribute to gathering important weather and climate data that will be used to forecast weather and monitor climate change in the Arctic!......

caption_original: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs MY rock!‚Äù . . ‚ÄúNo, Mine! GET OUT OF HERE!!‚Äù ... Just a couple of Northern Fulmars arguing about their resting spot on Prince Leopold Island‚Ä¶nothing a human couple wouldn‚Äôt do!Prince Leopold Island Sanctuary supports large numbers of four nesting species, including Thick-billed Murre, Northern Fulmar, Black-legged Kittiwake and Black Guillemot. The sanctuary is one of the most important multi-species seabird colonies in the Arctic, and is an important site for seabird research. Seabird monitoring has been ongoing since , generating one of the strongest datasets for seabird monitoring in the . YAY BIRD CONSERVATION!

caption_original: Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) biologist Steve Van Wilgenburg and Wildlife Tech Patrick Turgeon were working over the weekend, attaching automated recorders to trees in Greenwater Provincial Park (SK) to assist CWS monitor boreal forest bird populations. The acoustic recorders intermittently turn on and record the songs of species such as the Threatened Canada Warbler, which can then be identified by trained staff to allow biologists to determine species abundance and distribution. It also helps biologists determine which habitats are used by forest birds. CWS biologists use these recorders to go along with surveys normally conducted by trained staff primarily in the month of June.In March, access to wet areas is easier on snowshoes, and allows biologists to capture data on resident species such as grouse, owls, chickadees and woodpeckers that breed earlier than migrants returning from the tropics.......
